triplets: Edible fruit produced by the avocado tree (Persea americana), cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions
Eating raw, making guacamole, salads, smoothies, cooking, and baking
Fleshy fruit pulp, seed, and skin
Seed that can be planted to grow a new avocado tree
Skin that protects the fruit and varies in texture from smooth to rough
Flesh (edible part) rich in healthy fats, vitamins, and minerals
Green when unripe, turning darker green or yellowish when ripe; some varieties have purplish or blackish hues
Avocado tree, orchards, fruit supply chains, and tropical/subtropical agricultural ecosystems
Various farmers and horticulturists who cultivate avocado trees commercially or domestically
Typically 150–300 grams depending on variety and size
Approximately 7–20 cm in diameter depending on variety
Fruit can last 1–2 weeks after harvest under proper storage; the avocado tree itself can live and bear fruit for 50–70 years
